title: Week 3: January 12–18 - Genesis 1–2; Moses 2–3; Abraham 4–5
script:
Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. Imagine standing on the edge of a vast, empty void—nothing but darkness and chaos stretching endlessly before you. Then, with a single divine command, light pierces the gloom. Order begins to emerge. Land rises, waters part, and life bursts forth in vibrant color. This is the awe-inspiring story of the Creation as we find it in Genesis 1 and 2, Moses 2 and 3, and Abraham 4 and 5. Today, let’s step into this sacred narrative together, exploring not just how the world was made, but what it reveals about our Heavenly Father, Jesus Christ, and even ourselves.

Let’s start at the very beginning. In Genesis 1:1, we read, “In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.” Similarly, in Moses 2:1, the Lord declares, “I am the Beginning and the End, the Almighty God; by mine Only Begotten I created these things.” And in Abraham 4:1, we see the Gods—Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ—counseling together, saying, “Let us go down and organize.” Isn’t it remarkable to think about this divine teamwork? The earth wasn’t just thrown together; it was carefully planned and organized over time. Day by day, light, sky, land, seas, plants, animals—all came into being through Their loving, deliberate work. What does this tell you about God’s nature? How does it feel to know that the beauty of a sunset or the intricacy of a flower wasn’t an accident, but a gift crafted for you?

As we ponder these accounts, one truth stands out: God can bring order out of chaos. The earth was once “without form, and void” as Genesis 1:2 describes, or “empty and desolate” as Abraham 4:2 puts it. Yet, through His power, it became a place of life and wonder. Think about your own life for a moment. Are there areas that feel chaotic or empty right now? Maybe a struggle in your family, a personal doubt, or a sense of being lost? Take a quiet moment to reflect on this: just as God transformed the earth, He can bring light into your darkest moments. He can fill your emptiness with purpose. His creative work in you is not finished.

Building on that vision, let’s turn to a profound truth about who you are. In Genesis 1:26-27, we read, “And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth… So God created man in his own image, in the image of God created he him; male and female created he them.” This same truth echoes in Moses 2:26-27 and Abraham 4:26-27. Pause to let that resonate. You are created in the image of God—male and female, each of you bearing His divine imprint. What does that mean to you? How does it change the way you see yourself when you look in the mirror or the way you treat others around you?

This truth is so powerful because it reminds us of our potential. Being made in God’s likeness means you have the capacity to become like Him—exalted, glorified, heavenly. But it also means your body is sacred. It’s not just a shell; it’s a gift from your Creator. When the world tells you to criticize your appearance or compare yourself to others, remember this divine truth. How might knowing you’re created in God’s image help you overcome negative thoughts? Maybe it inspires you to care for your body with gratitude or to speak kindly to yourself and others.

This idea connects beautifully to another principle from the Creation story: our responsibility to care for God’s creations. In Genesis 1:28, after creating man and woman, God says, “Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it: and have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that moveth upon the earth.” We see this same charge in Moses 2:28 and Abraham 4:28. Dominion doesn’t mean to dominate or exploit—it means to steward with love and respect. Think about the earth around you—the trees, the animals, the rivers. How can you show reverence for God’s handiwork? Maybe it’s as simple as picking up litter on a walk or teaching your children to appreciate nature. Let that thought settle in your heart.

Notice how this pattern continues in the sacredness of marriage, another gift from the Creation. In Genesis 2:18, the Lord says, “It is not good that the man should be alone; I will make him an help meet for him.” Later, in verses 21-24, we see the beautiful union of Adam and Eve as they become “one flesh.” Moses 3:18 and 21-24, as well as Abraham 5:14-18, reaffirm this. Marriage between a man and a woman is ordained of God, designed to be a partnership of equals, sealed by His power for eternity. How can you honor this sacred covenant, whether in your own life or in the way you support others? Reflect on that for a second.

Finally, let’s consider one more gift from the Creation story: the Sabbath day. In Genesis 2:2-3, we read, “And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made. And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it.” This is mirrored in Moses 3:2-3 and Abraham 5:2-3. God made the Sabbath holy, a day set apart for rest and worship. What makes the Sabbath a blessing in your life? Is it a quiet moment to pray, time with family, or a chance to step away from the world’s noise? How can you make it a day that truly honors Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ?

As we close, let’s step back and marvel at the bigger picture. The Creation story isn’t just about the earth—it’s about you. It’s about a God who brings light from darkness, order from chaos, and who created you in His image with divine potential. It’s about a Savior who, by His power, made all things for your joy. It’s a reminder of your responsibility to care for this world, to honor sacred covenants like marriage, and to keep the Sabbath holy. Take a moment to let these truths sink deep into your soul.

I invite you to carry this with you through the week. Choose one way to show gratitude for being created in God’s image—maybe by speaking kindly to yourself or caring for your body as a sacred gift. Write down how it feels to remember who you really are. As you do, may you feel the love of your Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ, the Creators who are still shaping you into something magnificent.
